thread.title: Regulation OK with Uber, at a cost
thread.title_full: Regulation OK with Uber, at a cost | Business Spectator

author: AAP
title: Regulation OK with Uber, at a cost
text:
The Queensland manager of ride-sharing app Uber says the company would welcome regulation, but only under a revised system.
Uber marked one year of operations on the Gold Coast on Thursday, claiming it had provided more than 327,000 trips in the city over the past 12 months.
But the company's emergence has also resulted in a furious response from the established taxi industry, who claim Uber's model is illegal, endangers passengers and is unfair on those abiding by current regulations.
Uber Queensland general manager Mike Abbott says the company is eagerly anticipating a mooted state government review of the taxi industry, hoping the current legislation can be altered to include ride-sharing.
It costs over $500,000 to purchase a taxi licence in Queensland, while insurance costs for registered taxis are just under $10,000 per annum.
"We want to be able to be within the system," Mr Abbott told AAP.
"We're just looking for sensible safety-based legislation that encapsulates the industry-leading stuff we already do.
"We just don't want ridiculous licensing fees that I guess in a way is what this is all about."
Taxi licences aren't sold by the government in Queensland but are traded at a price determined by the market, although the government can issue new licences if deemed necessary.
Over 3200 licences exist in Queensland among some 2800 individual licence holders.
The Taxi Council of Queensland can't see a problem with the current system, which it maintains is determined by what other people are willing to pay to acquire a licence and designed to service the demand of the community.
"A TSL (taxi service licence) that is sold will be worth whatever a knowledgeable and willing buyer is prepared to pay under current market conditions," Taxi Council chief executive Benjamin Wash told AAP.
"It is worth noting as well that there have been no new licences released in Queensland since the 2013/2014 financial year as the model used to assess demand for taxi services has not indicated that there has been an increase in demand and hence no need for further licences."
Mr Abbott has also backed Uber's safety record despite a Gold Coast woman claiming earlier this month she had suffered a suspected broken leg and other injuries after being dragged out of a car and run over by an Uber driver.
